displayed_text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: to get things going. And so that’s why I put this appointment on the books. So let’s get the hormones started. You know you will say, “I want it; I don’t want it; I do want it.” In other words I’m not trying to put, you know but we have to have and then your opinion back. Family Member: Right. Doctor: So we weren’t making any decisions. So I’m delighted today that you feel better, that you can’t complain of anything. Patient: Right. Doctor: Your creatinine is down at one. And then if you’re still interested, then we would go for it. If you say, “I’m not interested”, if you’re not interested then you have to think about when do we start you know the chemotherapy. And that’s what we would probably do anyway. If you go through the process about the trial and they say you’re not eligible, then we would give the chemo anyway. Patient: Yeah anyway. Family Member: Now, at the end of the trial catheter, how do they go uh with that? Do they have to wait for the catheter to come out in order start clinical trials or or, Doctor: That’s after you’ve sat down with D and signed the paperwork. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Then they’ll do the extra tests to see that you’re eligible. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So there are steps and then if you’re working with a urologist and he or she is able to get it out, that’s great. If they feel like it needs to stay in and that isn’t something that excludes you from the study or that just will tell me that if I’m giving you chemotherapy your blood counts can get low. If your blood counts are low and you’ve got a tube in your bladder, you could have an infection. So that I might give you antibiotics to keep you from getting an infection because you’ve got the tube in.

Patient: Ah. Doctor: That’s a bad thing. Patient: Oh. Okay. Doctor: That says, um, (laughs) Patient: I see. Doctor: Uh. So you almost have to do something that’s not chemotherapy. Sorry. Something that’s not hormone therapy. Patient: Okay. Is that the – Doctor: Xtandi. Patient: Xtandi. Okay. That was a shot once a month or? Doctor: That was the pills you were taking. Patient: Oh, I did take them. Yeah. Okay. Doctor: So that would say if we did that just as a course of action and the likelihood it’s gonna help you is pretty low. Patient: Oh.

Patient: That’s different than this. Doctor: Yeah, because this this genotype that we're looking for- it does not predispose you to cancer. Patient: Okay. Doctor: This is something that's very common in the population. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We just think that these people are more likely to respond to antioxidants. Family Member: Mm. Doctor: But the, yeah, so the, I can print this out for you too, just so that you have it for your records. The testing to see if you have the hereditary risk of cancer was negative. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Alright, so of these options, what I think is reasonable, and what I think is not reasonable. Observation for you actually, I don't think is reasonable. You're a pretty healthy guy. You're a pretty healthy guy. And you don't have any comorbidities. You know, I would expect you to live if you didn't have prostate cancer, I would expect to live for at least another 10 years. So I think that we should do something more than observation, right? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. So this one would not be my first choice. Intermittent hormone therapy, I think if you wanted to go for a standard approach, like what everybody else is doing, I think that that is a very reasonable option. The downside is that you would be exposed to hormone therapy. And when we get to, if you ever get to this phase where you have metastatic disease where we can see your lymph nodes or see disease in the bones, you get started on hormonal hormone therapy anyways. So what usually happens in this approach is that you're getting it every six months. And, you know, maybe you get it for six months and you’re off of it for two years, maybe three years together for six months or a year, go for six months necessarily. This is certainly not a bad option. This is the standard option. This is what we consider the standard of care, like what's most widely accepted. And this could be an option now or later. You know, having talked to you before. I think what we should maybe try and do first is see if you'd be eligible and if you have this genotype for the MAP study.

Patient: Yeah, yes they are, yes they are. Doctor: Alright. Patient: Because you gave the thing last time on on on my uh calcium. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: They highered my calcium level now. Doctor: Let’s see what is this guys’ intake? Yeah it was too low last time. Patient: Yeah. Patient: Huh. Yeah bring in, lets take a look at it… Doctor: Yeah you’ll probably need the copy of the labs anyway. Patient: Yeah but that’s what… Doctor: You’ll have to take it to B____ too. Patient: Huh?

Patient: No, I think was the week before and you told me to stop. Doctor: Yeah. Right. Right. I think it's been at least two weeks. Patient: Yeah, at least two weeks. Doctor: Hopefully, it'll you know, flush out some more slowly get better. You know, the more natural thing you should ask her. She's gonna be the expert, you know, like melatonin. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Things like that. Family Member 1: He does try them. Patient: Yeah. That does help. Family Member 1: So, okay. Family Member 2: So how many milligrams of that could he take? Family Member 1: Like 10? Doctor: Well, you know, the reformulation is so different over the counter. Family Member 2: Mhmm.

Patient: So when I do get, when do I get my tickets? Doctor: Well, once, first, you have to sign the consent and do all the screening. Then we can register you and start booking the, the tickets, and whatnot. Patient: Here’s the papers I sign? Doctor: This is not the paper. Doctor: We have to bring you- Family Member: He didn’t care. Doctor: Multiple. Healthcare Professional: Excuse me. He did have labs done. Doctor: Yeah. He told me that. So the PSA is what? Healthcare Professional: Sixty. Doctor: Sixty? So here it’s sixty point four. (Sound Door closes) Patient: No. I want it. I want to get it over with.

Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: …it continues to rise. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: And in those patients we may offer radiation therapy, radiation therapy with hormonal therapy. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: But we’ll wait and see what happens in your case. Patient: I’ve been praying that… Doctor: We removed it and the fact that we removed it may minimize the reoccurrence. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: So we’ll see. Patient: Um hmm. Well that’s why I want to go that route you know. Doctor: Yeah and you did the right thing.

Patient: Right, right. Doctor: Depending on and the changes if they’re more than fifty percent – Patient: I don’t know chuckles]]. Doctor: - I’m okay with trying for it. Family Member: So what was that kaypo? Doctor: K-Y-P-H-O-P-L-A-S-T-Y. Kyphoplasty. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Yeah. But again you know these are things to ask him. Family Member: Right. Doctor: I don’t know if that… Patient: Well he had to get another… Family Member: Myogram.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: So alright well let’s, let’s continue with the same course. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And see what happens, alright? Patient: Um hum. I’ve been working and so, so you know, I’ve been keeping busy without that. Doctor: Okay. Okay. Alright. Very good. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And, uh, any other medical problems? Heart or lungs or anything like that? Patient: No. The only problem I have is with my knee. I had, uh, uh, a cyst. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: Erupt in my knee. Doctor: I see it.

Family Member: Because there isn’t any. Doctor: Right. Patient: Okay, And um, now with that, and I guess we can talk about it when we decide what we’re going to do. Does that involve a placebo? Doctor: Uhm. Patient: If that involves a placebo – Doctor: One of the two trials. The hormone therapy trial does involve a placebo. The other one does not. The radiotherapy trial does not. Patient: Uh hum, okay. Doctor: So if the placebo is a non-starter for you, then we skipped that as an option. But again just thinking broad terms first before we get into those details. Just thinking in broad terms so push off the for hormone therapy for a while and do a targeted radiotherapy instead. Or whether you feel that you just want to go ahead and give the hormone therapy to increase the chances of that lasting as long as possible or do some remission that lasts Patient: And yeah, but the way I’m going, I’d be the one in three. (laughs) Doctor: Okay. Patient: If I had it the other way I would have won the lottery. Doctor: I hear you. I hear you.

Patient: So I I I know you understand… Doctor: Real well. Patient: …everything that I’m saying. Doctor: Absolutely. No question. The anxiety is what the PSA is gonna be you know whether it’s gonna reoccur. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: All those things went through my mind is what’s going through yours. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: So… Patient: It took you a while to get to it? Doctor: Oh yeah. Patient: You know I just ask the question. Doctor: Oh yeah well absolutely, yeah.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: But when you’re on pills like that, experimental ones – Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You don’t want to have some big surgery, be scheduled in the middle of it. Doesn’t make sense. Because you have to do one at a time. Patient: I got you. Doctor: Because it’s a big sur – I mean it’s a big one. (Cell phone rings) Patient: So let me ask you this here, doc. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Do people come out of that surgery? Doctor: Oh, yeah! They do! (Cell phone rings) Patient: Right. Doctor: But it’s a start. So, what does that tell us? It’s aggressive, but we know that about your cancer. But, if we don’t talk about surgery as an option, then we didn’t do right by you because you know that that’s a possibility. What’s the root of all that? Well, it’s your cancer not controlled. That’s always the root of all evil. Not your bones, but your lymph nodes are growing. So, in this –

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.1 time: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::1 time

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.neutral: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::neutral

People of my ethnic group are treated th.neutral: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::neutral

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Unemployed for less than 1 year: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Unemployed for less than 1 year

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian

displayed_text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So in the short term you go down that route and do the other therapy and they monitor you on that, and then once that part of it’s completed you’d come back to – Patient: Um hum. Come back to you, okay. You stay in the loop somewhere. Doctor: My hands Dr.__ is also going to be in the loop because he is the one who referred you. Patient: Yes, yes, I’ll have to; I’ll make an appointment with him. I saw him about maybe about six weeks ago and he had mentioned that they were starting up some trials in GW. I’m more comfortable where I am now, to be very honest with you. Doctor: Uh hum. Patient: Because I think back to what I explained to you. Healthcare Professional: Right, right. Patient: Twenty-seventeen, somebody dropped the ball as far as I’m concerned. Healthcare Professional: Right, right. Patient: So I don’t have as much confidence in going back to that you know facility. Healthcare Professional: Right.

Patient: Right. Doctor: They come in, which, and you know when they looked at your picture um it really was where this was all started — that’s the problem because you can tell just by them just having to put a catheter in, that uh once your bladder gets empty and kidney functions get better. Patient: Right. Doctor: Uh yeah so those are issues we have to talk about whether or not there is any role for radiation even though that’s not going to fix the big problem. It may help you pee better. Patient: Uh hum. Family Member: Um now since the cancer has spread, that the main problem Doctor: Uh huh. Family Member: - and the prostate is enlarged. Does it make any sense to remove it? Doctor: No, we wouldn’t operate on it. We would potentially radiate it. Family Member: Okay. Patient: Yeah, I understood that it would not be removed. Family Member: Okay, so you need to advise us and…

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Umm. So, that would be sort of, in some ways, a gamble. But, some folks, everything we know about the drugs you’ve had so far, we’ve had people gamble at one point. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: And, then, the third one is we draw blood tests today, just to see the AR-V7 positive. That maybe that you say in what you’re doing now, and if you are AR-V7 positive, then we can sort of say, “Hey, yeah, let’s look at this other option,” if the immune therapy would be something that you would think about. Patient: Okay. What, what, what’s the, uh, uh, um likelihood of, of, if at that time the AR-V7, uh, testing comes back negative which means I can’t do that. Doctor: Right. Patient: Uh, and then look at the other options. So, is that, is the one that is phase one is that, that window like a real tight window. That seven days from now, it’s gonna be closed? Doctor: Umm. I don’t know that. So, when I spoke to Dr. P_, all she let me know was that there was a slot. You know, that would be something that we would say once you’ve decided or that we’ve given you the consent form that we have a potential patient who’s interested, that they would save that slot for you. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because they would, I assume, that there is going to need to be a twenty-eight day washout of your current therapy. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then, maybe that you have to repeat scans prior to that. Um, the adrenal glands. The, the big wild card there right now what I can clearly state that it is not specific. I don’t know what it is.
